chapter.title: Configuration
chapter.para: In order for RestComm to function properly it must first be configured. In this chapter we will cover the settings for RestComm and it's respective plug-ins. In order to make RestComm easy to manage all of the configuration is done in only one file. The file is located at RESTCOMM_HOME/WEB-INF/conf/restcomm.xml and is composed of the sections that follow.

note.para: RestComm provides a default set of plug-ins for the storage engine, fax service, SMS aggregator, automatic speech recognition, and speech synthesis. All these services are pluggable and RestComm is not limited to any service provider or software platform whom's services it consumes.

section.title: Runtime Settings
section.para: The runtime-settings are used by RestComm at runtime to customize it's behavior. A list of the runtime settings and a description is provided below.

row.entry: The version of the RestComm API that we will be executing by default.
The audio file to play for the 'beep' and 'playBeep' attributes.
The audio file to play for the <Reject> verb using the 'rejected' attribute.
The audio file to play when a participant enters a conference room.
The audio file to play when a participant exits a conference room.
The audio file to play when a caller is waiting for a call to be bridged using the <Dial> verb.
The default audio file to play in a conference room. This is equivalent to setting the waitUrl attribute for the <Conference> noun.
The root URI to the error dictionary. This dictionary contains descriptions and possible solutions to the error codes that RestComm will return as part of it's Notifications resource.
The path to the directory used to save recordings made by RestComm.
The user name used to authenticate with the outbound proxy. (Optional)
The password used to authenticated with the outbound proxy. (Optional)
The SIP URI to the outbound proxy. Note: Do not prepend 'sip:' to the proxy uri. If necessary the port can be included, for example thomas@localhost:5080

formalpara.title: Restcomm Resource Security
formalpara.para: The security model is based on role based access control. RestComm defines a set of permissions that can be defined for each role. There are two predefined roles Administrator and Developer. The Developer role can be configured or removed all together depending on your needs but the Administrator role can not be changed. The Administrator role can not be modified or removed and it has access to every resource.

section.para: First we will define the list of permissions and what they mean.

row.entry: The role has access to create a type resource.
The role has access to read a type of resource.
The role has access to modify a type of resource.
The role has access to delete a type of resource.

section.para: These permissions apply to every resource exposed by the Restful APIs. Once a role is defined it can be specified for new Account resources that are created.

note.para: If no role is specified when creating a new Account resource then the new Account will inherit the security role of the account that created it. If this role is the Administrator role the system may become compromised.

formalpara.title: Wildcard Permission
formalpara.para: The asterisk '*' is a wildcard that means grant all permissions and can be used in place of typing out all the permissions.

section.para: To see how this all comes together please check out the restcomm.xml configuration file.

section.title: Dao Manager
section.para: The data access object manager is used to gain access to the data store that RestComm will use.
The default data access object manager is based on MyBatis and provides access to RDBM systems. Alternatively, a MongoDB implementation is included.

row.entry: The path to the mybatis.xml configuration file.
The path to the data files used to store the database tables.
The path to the XML files containing the SQL statements that will be executed by the database.
The IP address or host name of MongoDB server.
The port on the MongoDB server to use.
The name of the database to use.
The user name used to authenticate with MongoDB (Optional).
The password used to authenticate with MongoDB (Optional).

section.title: Media Server Manager
section.para: The media server manager is responsible for all the media servers managed by RestComm. The media server manager is also responsible for load-balancing connections to the media servers that it manages. When configuring the media server manager multiple media servers can be defined. Below is a description of settings for each media server.

row.entry: The local IP address for the MGCP stack.
The local port for the MGCP stack.
The IP address for the media server.
The port for the media server.

note.para: Currently, load-balancing uses a naive round-robin implementation but in future implementations the algorithm will be based on media server load.

section.title: SMS Aggregator
section.para: The SMS aggregator is responsible for the handling of SMS messages on behalf of RestComm.

formalpara.title: Requirements
formalpara.para: The default SMS aggregator is Essendex. Therefore, an account must be created @ http://www.esendex.com before any text messages can be sent.

section.para: Below is a list of settings that must be configured to send text messages.

row.entry: The user name used to authenticate with Essendex.
The password used to authenticate with Essendex.
The account used to authenticate with Essendex.

section.title: Fax Service
section.para: The fax service sends faxes out on behalf of RestComm.

formalpara.title: Requirements
formalpara.para: The default fax service is provided by Interfax. Therefore, an account must be created @ http://www.interfax.net before any faxes can be sent.

row.entry: The user name used to authenticate with Interfax.
The password used to authenticate with Interfax.
The maximum files size allowed to be delivered via fax.
The timeout period before an undeliverable fax is considered as failed.

section.title: Speech Recognizer
section.para: This speech recognizer turns speech in to text on behalf of Restcomm.

formalpara.title: Requirements
formalpara.para: The default speech recognizer uses the ASR service provided by iSpeech. Therefore, an account must be created @ http://www.ispeech.org before any speech can be converted to text.

row.entry: The Web API key provide by iSpeech. This is used as an authentication token for the service.

section.title: Speech Synthesizer
section.para: The speech synthesizer turns text to speech on behalf of RestComm.

formalpara.title: Requirements
formalpara.para: The default speech synthesizer uses the TTS service provided by Acapela. Therefore, an account must be created @ http://www.acapela-vaas.com before any text can be converted to speech.

row.entry: The location on the file system to use for caching TTS results.
The acapela group service root URI.
The application used to authenticate with the acapela group.
The login used to authenticate with the acapela group.
The password used to authenticate with the acapela group.
A list of male and female speakers for different languages. These can be replaced with other alternatives provided by the acapela group.
